004

006import java.util.Arrays;
007import java.util.Iterator;
008import java.util.List;
009import java.util.Objects;
010
011import static squidpony.squidmath.NumberTools.doubleToMixedIntBits;
012import static squidpony.squidmath.NumberTools.floatToIntBits;
013
014/**
015 * Simple hashing functions that we can rely on staying the same cross-platform.
016 * The static methods of this class (not its inner classes) use a custom algorithm
017 * designed for speed and general-purpose usability, but not cryptographic security;
018 * this algorithm is sometimes referred to as Hive, and several other algorithms are
019 * available in static inner classes, some of which have different goals, such as
020 * reduced likelihood of successfully reversing a hash, or just providing another
021 * choice. The hashes this returns are always 0 when given null to hash. Arrays with
022 * identical elements of identical types will hash identically. Arrays with identical
023 * numerical values but different types will sometimes hash differently. This class
024 * always provides 64-bit hashes via hash64() and 32-bit hashes via hash(), and some
025 * of the algorithms here may provide a hash32() method that matches older behavior
026 * and uses only 32-bit math. The hash64() and hash() methods, at least in Wisp and
027 * Mist, use 64-bit math even when producing 32-bit hashes, for GWT reasons. GWT
028 * doesn't have the same behavior as desktop and Android applications when using ints
029 * because it treats doubles mostly like ints, sometimes, due to it using JavaScript.
030 * If we use mainly longs, though, GWT emulates the longs with a more complex
031 * technique behind-the-scenes, that behaves the same on the web as it does on
032 * desktop or on a phone. Since CrossHash is supposed to be stable cross-platform,
033 * this is the way we need to go, despite it being slightly slower.
034 * <br>
035 * There are several static inner classes in CrossHash: Lightning, Falcon, and Mist,
036 * each providing different hashing properties, as well as the inner IHasher interface and a
037 * compatibility version of Wisp as a subclass. Older versions of SquidLib encouraged using a
038 * subclass because the non-nested-class methods used a lousy implementation of the FNV-1a algorithm,
039 * which was roughly 10x slower than the current methods in CrossHash and had poor correlation
040 * properties. In the current version, you probably will be fine with the default functions in
041 * CrossHash, using the Wisp algorithm. If you need a salt to alter the hash function,
042 * using one of a large family of such functions instead of a single function like Wisp, then Mist
043 * is a good choice. Lightning is mostly superseded by Wisp, but it can have better behavior on some
044 * collections regarding collisions; Falcon is meant to be a faster version of Lightning.
045 * <br>
046 * IHasher values are provided as static fields, and use Wisp to hash a specific type or fall
047 * back to Object.hashCode if given an object with the wrong type. IHasher values are optional
048 * parts of OrderedMap, OrderedSet, Arrangement, and the various classes that use Arrangement
049 * like K2 and K2V1, and allow arrays to be used as keys in those collections while keeping
050 * hashing by value instead of the normal hashing by reference for arrays. You probably won't
051 * ever need to make a class that implements IHasher yourself; for some cases you may want to
052 * look at the {@link Hashers} class for additional functions.
053 * <br>
054 * The inner classes provide alternate, faster hashing algorithms. Lightning, Wisp, and Falcon
055 * have no theoretical basis or grounds in any reason other than empirical testing for why they
056 * do what they do, and this seems to be in line with many widely-used hashes (see: The Art of
057 * Hashing, http://eternallyconfuzzled.com/tuts/algorithms/jsw_tut_hashing.aspx ). That said, Wisp
058 * performs very well, ahead of Arrays.hashCode (10.5 ms instead of 15 ms) for over a million
059 * hashes of 16-element long arrays, not including overhead for generating them, while SipHash and
060 * FNV-1a take approximately 80 ms and 135-155 ms, respectively, for the same data). Lightning and
061 * Falcon perform less-well, with Lightning taking 17 ms instead of 15 ms for Arrays.hashCode, and
062 * Falcon taking about 12.3 ms but slowing down somewhat if a 32-bit hash is requested from long
063 * data. All of these have good, low, collision rates on Strings and long arrays. Sketch is only
064 * slightly slower than Wisp, but offers little to no advantage over it yet.
065 * <br>
066 * Mist is a variant on Wisp with 128 bits for a salt-like modifier as a member variable, which can
067 * make 2 to the 128 individual hashing functions from one set of code, and uses 64 bits for some other
068 * hashes (only calls to hash() with data that doesn't involve long or double arrays). Mist has some
069 * minor resemblance to a cryptographic hash, but is not recommended it for that usage. It is,
070 * however ideal for situations that show up often in game development where end users may be able
071 * to see and possibly alter some information that you don't want changed (i.e. save data stored on
072 * a device or in the browser's LocalStorage). If you want a way to verify the data is what you
073 * think it is, you can store a hash, using one of the many-possible hash functions this can
074 * produce, somewhere else and verify that the saved data has the hash it did last time; if the
075 * exact hashing function isn't known (or exact functions aren't known) by a tampering user,
076 * then it is unlikely they can make the hash match even if they can edit it. Mist is slightly slower
077 * than Wisp, at about 18 ms for Mist for the same data instead of Wisp's 10.5, but should never be
078 * worse than twice as slow as Arrays.hashCode, and is still about three times faster than the similar
079 * SipHash that SquidLib previously had here.
080 * <br>
081 * All of the hashes used here have about the same rate of collisions on identical data
082 * (testing used Arrays.hashCode, all the hashes in here now, and the now-removed SipHash), with
083 * any fluctuation within some small margin of error. Wisp (typically via the non-nested methods
084 * in CrossHash) and Mist are the two most likely algorithms you might use here.
085 * <br>
086 * To help find patterns in hash output in a visual way, you can hash an x,y point, take the bottom 24 bits,
087 * and use that as an RGB color for the pixel at that x,y point. On a 512x512 grid of points, the patterns
088 * in Arrays.hashCode and the former default CrossHash algorithm (FNV-1a) are evident, and Sip (implementing
089 * SipHash) did approximately as well as Lightning, with no clear patterns visible (Sip has been removed from
090 * SquidLib because it needs a lot of code and is slower than all of the current hashes). The idea is from
091 * <a href="http://www.clockandflame.com/media/Goulburn06.pdf">a technical report on visual uses for hashing (PDF)</a>.
092 * <ul>
093 * <li>{@link java.util.Arrays#hashCode(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/S4Gh1sX.png</li>
094 * <li>{@link CrossHash#hash(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/x8SDqvL.png</li>
095 * <li>(Former) CrossHash.Sip.hash(int[]): http://i.imgur.com/keSpIwm.png</li>
096 * <li>{@link CrossHash.Lightning#hash(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/afGJ9cA.png</li>
097 * </ul>
098 * <br>
099 * Note: This class was formerly called StableHash, but since that refers to a specific
100 * category of hashing algorithm that this is not, and since the goal is to be cross-
101 * platform, the name was changed to CrossHash.
102 * Note 2: FNV-1a was removed from SquidLib on July 25, 2017, and replaced as default with Wisp; Wisp
103 * was later replaced as default by Hive, and in June 2019 Hive was replaced by Water. Wisp was used
104 * because at the time SquidLib preferred 64-bit math when math needed to be the same across platforms;
105 * math on longs behaves the same on GWT as on desktop, despite being slower. Hive passed an older version
106 * of SMHasher, a testing suite for hashes, where Wisp does not (it fails just like Arrays.hashCode()
107 * does). Hive uses a cross-platform subset of the possible 32-bit math operations when producing 32-bit 
108 * hashes of data that doesn't involve longs or doubles, and this should speed up the CrossHash.Hive.hash()
109 * methods a lot on GWT, but it slows down 32-bit output on desktop-class JVMs. Water became the default
110 * when newer versions of SMHasher showed that Hive wasn't as high-quality as it had appeared, and the
111 * recently-debuted wyhash by Wang Yi, a variation on a hash called MUM, opened some possibilities for
112 * structures that are simple but also very fast. Water is modeled after wyhash and uses the same constants
113 * in its hash64() methods, but avoids the 128-bit multiplication that wyhash uses. Because both wyhash and
114 * Water operate on 4 items at a time, they tend to be very fast on desktop platforms, but Water probably
115 * won't be amazing at GWT performance.
116 * <br>
117 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 1/16/2016.
118 * @author Tommy Ettinger
119 */
120public class CrossHash {
121    public static long hash64(final CharSequence data) {
122        return Water.hash64(data);
123    }

157    /**
158     * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
159     *
160     * @param data  the char array to hash
161     * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
162     * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
163     * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
164     */
165    public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
166        return Water.hash64(data, start, end);
167    }

315    /**
316     * An interface that can be used to move the logic for the hashCode() and equals() methods from a class' methods to
317     * an implementation of IHasher that certain collections in SquidLib can use. Primarily useful when the key type is
318     * an array, which normally doesn't work as expected in Java hash-based collections, but can if the right collection
319     * and IHasher are used. See also {@link Hashers} for additional implementations, some of which need dependencies on
320     * things the rest of CrossHash doesn't, like a case-insensitive String hasher/equator that uses RegExodus to handle
321     * CharSequence comparison on GWT.
322     */
323    public interface IHasher extends Serializable {
324        /**
325         * If data is a type that this IHasher can specifically hash, this method should use that specific hash; in
326         * other situations, it should simply delegate to calling {@link Object#hashCode()} on data. The body of an
327         * implementation of this method can be very small; for an IHasher that is meant for byte arrays, the body could
328         * be: {@code return (data instanceof byte[]) ? CrossHash.Lightning.hash((byte[]) data) : data.hashCode();}
329         *
330         * @param data the Object to hash; this method should take any type but often has special behavior for one type
331         * @return a 32-bit int hash code of data
332         */
333        int hash(final Object data);
334
335        /**
336         * Not all types you might want to use an IHasher on meaningfully implement .equals(), such as array types; in
337         * these situations the areEqual method helps quickly check for equality by potentially having special logic for
338         * the type this is meant to check. The body of implementations for this method can be fairly small; for byte
339         * arrays, it looks like: {@code return left == right
340         * || ((left instanceof byte[] && right instanceof byte[])
341         * ? Arrays.equals((byte[]) left, (byte[]) right)
342         * : Objects.equals(left, right));} , but for multidimensional arrays you should use the
343         * {@link #equalityHelper(Object[], Object[], IHasher)} method with an IHasher for the inner arrays that are 1D
344         * or otherwise already-hash-able, as can be seen in the body of the implementation for 2D char arrays, where
345         * charHasher is an existing IHasher that handles 1D arrays:
346         * {@code return left == right
347         * || ((left instanceof char[][] && right instanceof char[][])
348         * ? equalityHelper((char[][]) left, (char[][]) right, charHasher)
349         * : Objects.equals(left, right));}
350         *
351         * @param left  allowed to be null; most implementations will have special behavior for one type
352         * @param right allowed to be null; most implementations will have special behavior for one type
353         * @return true if left is equal to right (preferably by value, but reference equality may sometimes be needed)
354         */
355        boolean areEqual(final Object left, final Object right);
356    }
357
358    /**
359     * Not a general-purpose method; meant to ease implementation of {@link IHasher#areEqual(Object, Object)}
360     * methods when the type being compared is a multi-dimensional array (which normally requires the heavyweight method
361     * {@link Arrays#deepEquals(Object[], Object[])} or doing more work yourself; this reduces the work needed to
362     * implement fixed-depth equality). As mentioned in the docs for {@link IHasher#areEqual(Object, Object)}, example
363     * code that hashes 2D char arrays can be done using an IHasher for 1D char arrays called charHasher:
364     * {@code return left == right
365     * || ((left instanceof char[][] && right instanceof char[][])
366     * ? equalityHelper((char[][]) left, (char[][]) right, charHasher)
367     * : Objects.equals(left, right));}
368     *
369     * @param left an array of some kind of Object, usually an array, that the given IHasher can compare
370     * @param right an array of some kind of Object, usually an array, that the given IHasher can compare
371     * @param inner an IHasher to compare items in left with items in right
372     * @return true if the contents of left and right are equal by the given IHasher, otherwise false
373     */
374    public static boolean equalityHelper(Object[] left, Object[] right, IHasher inner) {
375        if (left == right)
376            return true;
377        if (left == null || right == null || left.length != right.length)
378            return false;
379        for (int i = 0; i < left.length; i++) {
380            if (!inner.areEqual(left[i], right[i]))
381                return false;
382        }
383        return true;
384    }
385
386    private static class BooleanHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
387        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
388
389        BooleanHasher() {
390        }
391
392        @Override
393        public int hash(final Object data) {
394            return (data instanceof boolean[]) ? CrossHash.hash((boolean[]) data) : data.hashCode();
395        }
396
397        @Override
398        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
399            return left == right || ((left instanceof boolean[] && right instanceof boolean[]) ? Arrays.equals((boolean[]) left, (boolean[]) right) : Objects.equals(left, right));
400        }
401    }
402
403    public static final IHasher booleanHasher = new BooleanHasher();
404
405    private static class ByteHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
406        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
407
408        ByteHasher() {
409        }
410
411        @Override
412        public int hash(final Object data) {
413            return (data instanceof byte[]) ? CrossHash.hash((byte[]) data) : data.hashCode();
414        }
415
416        @Override
417        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
418            return left == right
419                    || ((left instanceof byte[] && right instanceof byte[])
420                    ? Arrays.equals((byte[]) left, (byte[]) right)
421                    : Objects.equals(left, right));
422        }
423    }
424
425    public static final IHasher byteHasher = new ByteHasher();
426

541    private static class Char2DHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
542        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
543
544        Char2DHasher() {
545        }
546
547        @Override
548        public int hash(final Object data) {
549            return (data instanceof char[][]) ? CrossHash.hash((char[][]) data) : data.hashCode();
550        }
551
552        @Override
553        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
554            return left == right
555                    || ((left instanceof char[][] && right instanceof char[][])
556                    ? equalityHelper((char[][]) left, (char[][]) right, charHasher)
557                    : Objects.equals(left, right));
558        }
559    }
560
561    public static final IHasher char2DHasher = new Char2DHasher();
562

571            return (data instanceof int[][]) ? CrossHash.hash((int[][]) data) : data.hashCode();
572        }
573
574        @Override
575        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
576            return left == right
577                    || ((left instanceof int[][] && right instanceof int[][])
578                    ? equalityHelper((int[][]) left, (int[][]) right, intHasher)
579                    : Objects.equals(left, right));
580        }
581    }

606
607    private static class StringHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
608        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
609
610        StringHasher() {
611        }
612
613        @Override
614        public int hash(final Object data) {
615            return (data instanceof CharSequence) ? CrossHash.hash((CharSequence) data) : data.hashCode();
616        }
617
618        @Override
619        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
620            return Objects.equals(left, right);
621        }
622    }
623
624    public static final IHasher stringHasher = new StringHasher();
625
626    private static class StringArrayHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
627        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
628
629        StringArrayHasher() {
630        }
631
632        @Override
633        public int hash(final Object data) {
634            return (data instanceof CharSequence[]) ? CrossHash.hash((CharSequence[]) data) : data.hashCode();
635        }
636
637        @Override
638        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
639            return left == right || ((left instanceof CharSequence[] && right instanceof CharSequence[]) ? equalityHelper((CharSequence[]) left, (CharSequence[]) right, stringHasher) : Objects.equals(left, right));
640        }
641    }
642
643    /**
644     * Though the name suggests this only hashes String arrays, it can actually hash any CharSequence array as well.
645     */
646    public static final IHasher stringArrayHasher = new StringArrayHasher();
647
648    private static class ObjectArrayHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
649        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
650
651        ObjectArrayHasher() {
652        }
653
654        @Override
655        public int hash(final Object data) {
656            return (data instanceof Object[]) ? CrossHash.hash((Object[]) data) : data.hashCode();
657        }
658
659        @Override
660        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
661            return left == right || ((left instanceof Object[] && right instanceof Object[]) && Arrays.equals((Object[]) left, (Object[]) right) || Objects.equals(left, right));
662        }
663    }
664    public static final IHasher objectArrayHasher = new ObjectArrayHasher();
665
666    private static class DefaultHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
667        private static final long serialVersionUID = 5L;
668
669        DefaultHasher() {
670        }
671
672        @Override
673        public int hash(final Object data) {
674            if(data == null) return 0;
675            final int x = data.hashCode() * 0x9E375;
676            return x ^ x >>> 16;
677        }
678
679        @Override
680        public boolean areEqual(final Object left, final Object right) {
681            return (left == right) || (left != null && left.equals(right));
682        }
683    }
684
685    public static final IHasher defaultHasher = new DefaultHasher();
686
687    private static class MildHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
688        private static final long serialVersionUID = 4L;
689
690        MildHasher() {
691        }
692
693        @Override
694        public int hash(final Object data) {
695            return data != null ? data.hashCode() : 0;
696        }
697
698        @Override
699        public boolean areEqual(final Object left, final Object right) {
700            return (left == right) || (left != null && left.equals(right));
701        }
702    }
703
704    /**
705     * The most basic IHasher type; effectively delegates to {@link Objects#hashCode(Object)} and
706     * {@link Objects#equals(Object, Object)}. Might not scramble the bits of a hash well enough to have good
707     * performance in a hash table lke {@link OrderedMap} or {@link UnorderedSet}, unless the objects being hashed have
708     * good hashCode() implementations already.
709     */
710    public static final IHasher mildHasher = new MildHasher();
711
712    private static class IdentityHasher implements IHasher, Serializable
713    {
714        private static final long serialVersionUID = 4L;
715        IdentityHasher() { }
716
717        @Override
718        public int hash(Object data) {
719            return System.identityHashCode(data);
720        }
721
722        @Override
723        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
724            return left == right;
725        }
726    }
727    public static final IHasher identityHasher = new IdentityHasher();
728
729    private static class GeneralHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
730        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
731
732        GeneralHasher() {
733        }
734
735        @Override
736        public int hash(final Object data) {
737            return CrossHash.hash(data);
738        }
739
740        @Override
741        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
742            if(left == right) return true;
743            Class l = left.getClass(), r = right.getClass();
744            if(l == r)
745            {
746                if(l.isArray())
747                {
748                    if(left instanceof int[]) return Arrays.equals((int[]) left, (int[]) right);
749                    else if(left instanceof long[]) return Arrays.equals((long[]) left, (long[]) right);
750                    else if(left instanceof char[]) return Arrays.equals((char[]) left, (char[]) right);
751                    else if(left instanceof double[]) return Arrays.equals((double[]) left, (double[]) right);
752                    else if(left instanceof boolean[]) return Arrays.equals((boolean[]) left, (boolean[]) right);
753                    else if(left instanceof byte[]) return Arrays.equals((byte[]) left, (byte[]) right);
754                    else if(left instanceof float[]) return Arrays.equals((float[]) left, (float[]) right);
755                    else if(left instanceof short[]) return Arrays.equals((short[]) left, (short[]) right);
756                    else if(left instanceof char[][]) return equalityHelper((char[][]) left, (char[][]) right, charHasher);
757                    else if(left instanceof int[][]) return equalityHelper((int[][]) left, (int[][]) right, intHasher);
758                    else if(left instanceof long[][]) return equalityHelper((long[][]) left, (long[][]) right, longHasher);
759                    else if(left instanceof CharSequence[]) return equalityHelper((CharSequence[]) left, (CharSequence[]) right, stringHasher);
760                    else if(left instanceof Object[]) return Arrays.equals((Object[]) left, (Object[]) right);
761                }
762                return Objects.equals(left, right);
763            }
764            return false;
765        }
766    }
767
768    /**
769     * This IHasher is the one you should use if you aren't totally certain what types will go in an OrderedMap's keys
770     * or an OrderedSet's items, since it can handle mixes of elements.
771     */
772    public static final IHasher generalHasher = new GeneralHasher();
773
774    /**
775     * A quick, simple hashing function that seems to have good results. Like LightRNG, it stores a state that
776     * it updates independently of the output, and this starts at a large prime. At each step, it takes the
777     * current item in the array being hashed, adds a large non-prime used in LightRNG's generation function
778     * (it's 2 to the 64, times the golden ratio phi, and truncated to a signed long), multiplies by a prime
779     * called the "state multiplier", adds the result to the state and stores it, multiplies the value of the
780     * state by another prime called the "output multiplier", then XORs the current result with that value
781     * before moving onto the next item in the array. A finalization step XORs the result with a complex value
782     * made by adding the state (left over from the previous step) to what was the output multiplier, adding
783     * the last known value for result to the phi-related constant from LightRNG, multiplying that pair, adding
784     * the initial state (which turns out to be unusually good for this, despite no particularly special numeric
785     * qualities other than being a probable prime) and then bitwise-rotating it left by a seemingly-random
786     * number drawn from the highest 6 bits of the state.
787     * <br>
788     * This all can be done very quickly; a million hashes of a million different 16-element long arrays can be
789     * computed in under 18-20 ms (in the benchmark, some amount of that is overhead from generating a new
790     * array with LongPeriodRNG, since the benchmark uses that RNG's state for data, and the default
791     * Arrays.hashCode implementation is only somewhat faster at under 16 ms). After several tries and tweaks
792     * to the constants this uses, it also gets remarkably few hash collisions. On the same 0x100000, or
793     * 1048576, RNG states for data, Lightning gets 110 collisions, the JDK Arrays.hashCode method gets 129
794     * collisions, Sip (implementing SipHash) gets 145 collisions, and CrossHash (using the FNV-1a algorithm)
795     * gets 135 collisions. Dispersion is not perfect, but
796     * at many bit sizes Lightning continues to have less collisions (it disperses better than the other hashes
797     * with several quantities of bits, at least on this test data). Lightning also does relatively well, though
798     * it isn't clearly ahead of the rest all the time, when hashing Strings, especially ones that use a larger
799     * set of letters, it seems (FakeLanguageGen was used to make test data, and languages that used more
800     * characters in their alphabet seemed to hash better with this than competing hashes for some reason).
801     * <br>
802     * There is certainly room for improvement with the specific numbers chosen; earlier versions used the
803     * state multiplier "Neely's number", which is a probable prime made by taking the radix-29 number
804     * "HARGNALLINSCLOPIOPEEPIO" (a reference to a very unusual TV show), truncating to 64 bits, and rotating
805     * right by 42 bits. This version uses "Neely's number" for an initial state and during finalization, and
806     * uses a different probable prime as the state multiplier, made with a similar process; it starts with the
807     * radix-36 number "EDSGERWDIJKSTRA", then does the same process but rotates right by 37 bits to obtain a
808     * different prime. This tweak seems to help with hash collisions. Extensive trial and error was used to
809     * find the current output multiplier, which has no real relationship to anything else but has exactly 32 of
810     * 64 bits set to 1, has 1 in the least and most significant bit indices (meaning it is negative and odd),
811     * and other than that seems to have better results on most inputs for mystifying reasons. Earlier versions
812     * applied a Gray code step to alter the output instead of a multiplier that heavily overflows to obfuscate
813     * state, but that had a predictable pattern for most of the inputs tried, which seemed less-than-ideal for
814     * a hash. Vitally, Lightning avoids predictable collisions that Arrays.hashCode has, like
815     * {@code Arrays.hashCode(new long[]{0})==Arrays.hashCode(new long[]{-1})}.
816     * <br>
817     * The output multiplier is 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L, the state multiplier is 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL, the number
818     * added to the state (from LightRNG and code derived from FastUtil, but obtained from the golden ratio
819     * phi) is 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L, and the starting state ("Neely's Number") is 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L.
820     * <br>
821     * To help find patterns in hash output in a visual way, you can hash an x,y point, take the bottom 24 bits,
822     * and use that as an RGB color for the pixel at that x,y point. On a 512x512 grid of points, the patterns
823     * in Arrays.hashCode and the default CrossHash algorithm (FNV-1a) are evident, and Sip (implementing
824     * SipHash) does approximately as well as Lightning, with no clear patterns visible (Sip has been removed
825     * from SquidLib because it needs a lot of code and is slower than Mist). The
826     * idea is from a technical report on visual uses for hashing,
827     * http://www.clockandflame.com/media/Goulburn06.pdf .
828     * <ul>
829     * <li>{@link java.util.Arrays#hashCode(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/S4Gh1sX.png</li>
830     * <li>{@link CrossHash#hash(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/x8SDqvL.png</li>
831     * <li>(Former) CrossHash.Sip.hash(int[]): http://i.imgur.com/keSpIwm.png</li>
832     * <li>{@link CrossHash.Lightning#hash(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/afGJ9cA.png</li>
833     * </ul>
834     */
835    // tested output multipliers
836    // 0x DA1A459BD9B4C619L
837    // 0x DC1A459879B5C619L
838    // 0x DC1A479829B5E639L
839    // 0x DC1A479C29B5C639L
840    // 0x EA1C479692B5C639L
841    // 0x CA1C479692B5C635L // this gets 105 collisions, low
842    // 0x CABC479692B5C635L
843    // 0x DC1A479C29B5C647L
844    // 0x DC1A479C29B5C725L
845    // 0x CABC279692B5CB21L
846    // 0x C6BC279692B5CC83L // this gets 100 collisions, lowest
847    // 0x C6BC279692B4D8A5L
848    // 0x C6BC279692B4D345L
849    // 0x C6EC273692B4A4B9L
850    // 0x C6A3256B52D5B463L
851    // 0x C6A3256B52D5B463L
852    // 0x C6A3256D52D5B4C9L
853    // 0x D8A3256D52D5B619L
854    // 0x D96E6AC724658947L
855    // 0x D96E6AC724658C2DL
856    // 0x CCABF9E32FD684F9L
857    // 0x C314163FAF912A01L
858    // 0x C3246007A332C12AL
859    // 0x CA1C479692B5C6ABL
860    // 0x C6B5275692B5CC83 // untested so far
861    @SuppressWarnings("NumericOverflow")
862    public static final class Lightning {
863
864        public static long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
865            if (data == null)
866                return 0;
867            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
868            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
869                result ^= (z += (data[i] ? 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L : 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
870            }
871            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
872        }
873
874        public static long hash64(final byte[] data) {
875            if (data == null)
876                return 0;
877            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
878            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
879                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
880            }
881            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
882        }
883
884        public static long hash64(final short[] data) {

889                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
890            }
891            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
892        }

901            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
902        }

912        }

914        public static long hash64(final long[] data) {
915            if (data == null)
916                return 0;
917            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
918            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
919                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
920            }
921            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
922        }
923
924        public static long hash64(final float[] data) {
925            if (data == null)
926                return 0;
927            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
928            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
929                result ^= (z += (floatToIntBits(data[i]) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
930            }
931            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
932        }
933
934        public static long hash64(final double[] data) {
935            if (data == null)
936                return 0;
937            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
938            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
939                result ^= (z += (NumberTools.doubleToMixedIntBits(data[i]) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
940            }
941            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
942        }
943
944        /**
945         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
946         *
947         * @param data  the char array to hash
948         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
949         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
950         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
951         */
952        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
953            if (data == null || start >= end)
954                return 0;
955            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
956            for (int i = start; i < end && i < data.length; i++) {
957                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
958            }
959            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
960        }
961        /**
962         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
963         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
964         *
965         * @param data  the char array to hash
966         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
967         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
968         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
969         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
970         */
971        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
972            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
973                return 0;
974            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
975            for (int i = start; i < end && i < data.length; i += step) {
976                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
977            }
978            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
979        }
980
981        public static long hash64(final CharSequence data) {
982            if (data == null)
983                return 0;
984            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
985            for (int i = 0; i < data.length(); i++) {
986                result ^= (z += (data.charAt(i) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
987            }
988            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
989        }
990
991        public static long hash64(final char[][] data) {
992            if (data == null)
993                return 0;
994            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
995            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
996                result ^= (z += (hash64(data[i]) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
997            }
998            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
999        }
1000
1001        public static long hash64(final long[][] data) {
1002            if (data == null)
1003                return 0;
1004            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1005            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
1006                result ^= (z += (hash64(data[i]) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1007            }
1008            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
1009        }
1010
1011        public static long hash64(final CharSequence[] data) {
1012            if (data == null)
1013                return 0;
1014            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1015            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
1016                result ^= (z += (hash64(data[i]) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1017            }
1018            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
1019        }
1020
1021        public static long hash64(final Iterable<? extends CharSequence> data) {
1022            if (data == null)
1023                return 0;
1024            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1025            for (CharSequence datum : data) {
1026                result ^= (z += (hash64(datum) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1027            }
1028            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
1029        }
1030
1031        public static long hash64(final CharSequence[]... data) {
1032            if (data == null)
1033                return 0;
1034            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1035            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
1036                result ^= (z += (hash64(data[i]) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1037            }
1038            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
1039        }
1040
1041        public static long hash64(final Object[] data) {
1042            if (data == null)
1043                return 0;
1044            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1045            Object o;
1046            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
1047                o = data[i];
1048                result ^= (z += ((o == null ? 0 : o.hashCode()) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1049            }
1050            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
1051        }

1058                result ^= (z += (data[i] ? 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L : 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;

1134        /**
1135         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
1136         *
1137         * @param data  the char array to hash
1138         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1139         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1140         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1141         */
1142        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
1143            if (data == null || start >= end)
1144                return 0;
1145
1146            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1147            for (int i = start; i < end && i < data.length; i++) {
1148                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1149            }
1150            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));
1151        }
1152        /**
1153         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
1154         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
1155         *
1156         * @param data  the char array to hash
1157         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1158         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1159         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
1160         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1161         */
1162        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
1163            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
1164                return 0;
1165
1166            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1167            for (int i = start; i < end && i < data.length; i += step) {
1168                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1169            }
1170            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));
1171        }
1172
1173        public static int hash(final CharSequence data) {
1174            if (data == null)
1175                return 0;
1176            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1177            for (int i = 0; i < data.length(); i++) {
1178                result ^= (z += (data.charAt(i) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1179            }
1180            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));
1181        }

1191        }

1213        public static int hash(final Iterable<? extends CharSequence> data) {

1221        }

1223        public static int hash(final CharSequence[]... data) {

1227            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
1228                result ^= (z += (hash64(data[i]) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1229            }
1230            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));
1231        }
1232
1233        public static int hash(final Object[] data) {
1234            if (data == null)
1235                return 0;
1236            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1237            Object o;
1238            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
1239                o = data[i];
1240                result ^= (z += ((o == null ? 0 : o.hashCode()) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1241            }
1242            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));
1243        }
1244    }
1245
1246    // Nice ints, all probable primes except the last one, for 32-bit hashing
1247    // 0x62E2AC0D 0x632BE5AB 0x85157AF5 0x9E3779B9
1248    /**
1249     * The fastest hash in CrossHash, with middling quality. Uses a finely-tuned mix of very few operations for each
1250     * element, plus a minimal and simple finalization step, and as such obtains superior speed on the standard
1251     * benchmark SquidLib uses for hashes (hashing one million 16-element long arrays, remaining the best in both 32-bit
1252     * and 64-bit versions). Specifically, Wisp takes 9.478 ms to generate a million 64-bit hashes on a recent laptop
1253     * with an i7-6700HQ processor (removing the time the control takes to generate the million arrays). For comparison,
1254     * the JDK's Arrays.hashCode method takes 13.642 ms on the same workload, though it produces 32-bit hashes. Wisp
1255     * performs almost exactly as well producing 32-bit hashes as it does 64-bit hashes, where Hive slows down
1256     * significantly on some input types. This also passes visual tests where an earlier version of Wisp did not.
1257     * Collision rates are slightly worse than other CrossHash classes, but are better than the JDK's
1258     * Arrays.hashCode method, that is, acceptably low when given varied-enough inputs. On certain kinds of similar
1259     * inputs, Wisp will struggle with a higher collision rate. For example, when hashing Strings that contain only
1260     * several spaces, then some combination of digits 0-5, then more spaces, Wisp does very badly, worse than
1261     * {@link String#hashCode()} (which also does badly, though not as badly), while other hashes here do fine (such as
1262     * Water, which is the default for {@link CrossHash#hash(CharSequence)}).
1263     * <br>
1264     * This version replaces an older version of Wisp that had serious quality issues and wasn't quite as fast. Since
1265     * the only reason one would use the older version was speed without regard for quality, and it was marked as Beta,
1266     * a faster version makes sense to replace the slower one, rather than add yet another nested class in CrossHash.
1267     * <br>
1268     * Wisp is no longer considered Beta-quality, but even though it is rather fast, it has some cases where categories
1269     * of input cause frequent collisions. {@link Water} is about 20% slower but doesn't have such categories of
1270     * pathologically bad inputs, and passes tests that Wisp fails badly on. Because the hash-based collections in
1271     * SquidLib need a pretty good hash function to work at their best (they use linear-probing with open addressing,
1272     * which struggles when hashes are bad), 20% loss of speed during hashing to avoid slower
1273     * lookups/insertions/deletions from {@link OrderedMap}, {@link OrderedSet}, {@link UnorderedMap},
1274     * {@link UnorderedSet}, {@link Arrangement}, and others is probably worth it; if you really need speed then Wisp is
1275     * right here.
1276     */
1277    public static final class Wisp {
1278        public static long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
1279            if (data == null)
1280                return 0;
1281            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1282            final int len = data.length;
1283            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
1284                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * (data[i] ? 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L : 0xAEF17502108EF2D9L));
1285            }
1286            return result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
1287        }
1288
1289        public static long hash64(final byte[] data) {
1290            if (data == null)
1291                return 0;
1292            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1293            final int len = data.length;
1294            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
1295                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]);
1296            }
1297            return result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
1298        }
1299

1309        }

1366        public static long hash64(final CharSequence data) {

1371            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {

1373            }

1377        /**
1378         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
1379         *
1380         * @param data  the char array to hash
1381         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1382         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1383         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1384         */
1385        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
1386            if (data == null || start >= end)
1387                return 0;
1388            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1389            final int len = end < data.length ? end : data.length;
1390            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1391                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]);
1392            }
1393            return result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
1394        }

1396        /**
1397         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
1398         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
1399         *
1400         * @param data  the char array to hash
1401         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1402         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1403         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
1404         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1405         */
1406        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
1407            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
1408                return 0;
1409            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1410            final int len = end < data.length ? end : data.length;
1411            for (int i = start; i < len; i += step) {
1412                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]);
1413            }
1414            return result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
1415        }

1419                return 0;
1420            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1421            final int len = data.length;
1422            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
1423                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * hash64(data[i]));
1424            }
1425            return result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
1426        }

1439        public static long hash64(final long[][] data) {

1448        }

1589        public static int hash32(final double[] data) {
1590            if (data == null)
1591                return 0;

1593            final int len = data.length;
1594            double t;
1595            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
1596                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * ((long) (-0xD0E8.9D2D311E289Fp-25 * (t = data[i]) + t * -0x1.39b4dce80194cp9)));
1597            }
1598            return (int)((result = (result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27))) ^ (result >>> 32));
1599        }

1611
1612        /**
1613         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
1614         * Uses 32-bit math on most platforms, but will give different results on GWT due to it using double values that
1615         * only somewhat act like int values.
1616         * @param data  the char array to hash
1617         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1618         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1619         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1620         */
1621        public static int hash32(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
1622            if (data == null || start >= end)
1623                return 0;
1624            int result = 0x9E3779B9, a = 0x632BE5AB;
1625            final int len = end < data.length ? end : data.length;
1626            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1627                result += (a ^= 0x85157AF5 * data[i]);
1628            }
1629            return result * (a | 1) ^ (result >>> 11 | result << 21);
1630        }
1631
1632        public static int hash32(final char[][] data) {

1637            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
1638                result += (a ^= 0x85157AF5 * hash32(data[i]));
1639            }
1640            return result * (a | 1) ^ (result >>> 11 | result << 21);
1641        }

1824        /**
1825         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
1826         *
1827         * @param data  the char array to hash
1828         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1829         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1830         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1831         */
1832        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
1833            if (data == null || start >= end)
1834                return 0;
1835            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1836            final int len = end < data.length ? end : data.length;
1837            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1838                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]);
1839            }
1840            return (int)(result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
1841        }

1843        /**
1844         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
1845         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
1846         *
1847         * @param data  the char array to hash
1848         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1849         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1850         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
1851         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1852         */
1853        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
1854            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
1855                return 0;
1856            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1857            final int len = end < data.length ? end : data.length;
1858            for (int i = start; i < len; i+= step) {
1859                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]);
1860            }
1861            return (int)(result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
1862        }

1943            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1944            final int len = data.length;
1945            Object o;
1946            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
1947                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * ((o = data[i]) == null ? -1 : o.hashCode()));
1948            }
1949            return (int)(result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
1950        }
1951
1952        public static int hash(final Object data) {
1953            if (data == null)
1954                return 0;
1955            long a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L ^ 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data.hashCode(), result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + a;
1956            return (int)(result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
1957        }
1958
1959    }
1960
1961    /**
1962     * A whole cluster of Wisp-like hash functions that sacrifice a small degree of speed, but can be built with up
1963     * to 128 bits of salt values that help to obscure what hashing function is actually being used. This class is
1964     * similar to the older Storm variety, but is somewhat faster and has many more possible salt "states" when using
1965     * the constructors that take two longs or a CharSequence. There isn't really any reason to use Storm, so Mist has
1966     * now replaced Storm entirely. Code that used Storm should be able to just change any usage of "Storm" to "Mist".
1967     * <br>
1968     * The salt fields are not serialized, so it is important that the same salt will be given by the
1969     * program when the same hash results are wanted for some inputs.
1970     * <br>
1971     * A group of 48 static, final, pre-initialized Mist members are present in this class, 24 with the
1972     * name of a letter in the Greek alphabet (this uses the convention on Wikipedia,
1973     * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_alphabet#Letters , where lambda is spelled with a 'b') and 24 with the same
1974     * name followed by an underscore, such as {@link #alpha_}. The whole group of 48 pre-initialized members are also
1975     * present in a static array called {@code predefined}. These can be useful when, for example, you want to get
1976     * multiple hashes of a single array or String as part of cuckoo hashing or similar techniques that need multiple
1977     * hashes for the same inputs.
1978     */
1979    @Beta
1980    public static final class Mist implements Serializable {
1981        private static final long serialVersionUID = -1275284837479983271L;
1982
1983        private transient final long $l1, $l2;
1984
1985        public Mist() {
1986            this(0x1234567876543210L, 0xEDCBA98789ABCDEFL);
1987        }
1988
1989        public Mist(final CharSequence alteration) {
1990            this(CrossHash.hash64(alteration), Lightning.hash64(alteration));
1991        }
1992        private static int permute(final long state)
1993        {
1994            int s = (int)state ^ 0xD0E89D2D;
1995            s = (s >>> 19 | s << 13);
1996            s ^= state >>> (5 + (state >>> 59));
1997            return ((s *= 277803737) >>> 22) ^ s;
1998        }
1999
2000        @SuppressWarnings("NumericOverflow")
2001        public Mist(final long alteration) {
2002            long l1, l2;
2003            l1 = alteration + permute(alteration);
2004            l1 = (l1 ^ (l1 >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
2005            l1 = (l1 ^ (l1 >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
2006            $l1 = l1 ^ l1 >>> 31;
2007
2008            l2 = alteration + 6 * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
2009            l2 = (l2 ^ (l2 >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
2010            l2 = (l2 ^ (l2 >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
2011            $l2 = l2 ^ l2 >>> 31;
2012        }
2013
2014        @SuppressWarnings("NumericOverflow")
2015        public Mist(final long alteration1, long alteration2) {
2016            final int i1 = permute(alteration1);
2017            $l1 = alteration1 + i1;
2018            $l2 = alteration2 + permute(alteration2 + i1);
2019        }
2020
2021        /**
2022         * Makes a new Mist with all of the salt values altered based on the previous salt values.
2023         * This will make a different, incompatible Mist object that will give different results than the original.
2024         * Meant for use in Cuckoo Hashing, which can need the hash function to be updated or changed.
2025         * An alternative is to select a different Mist object from {@link #predefined}, or to simply
2026         * construct a new Mist with a different parameter or set of parameters.
2027         */
2028        @SuppressWarnings("NumericOverflow")
2029        public Mist randomize()
2030        {
2031            long l1, l2;
2032            l1 = $l2 + permute($l2 + 3 * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L);
2033            l1 = (l1 ^ (l1 >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
2034            l1 = (l1 ^ (l1 >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
2035            l1 ^= l1 >>> 31;
2036
2037            l2 = permute(l1 + 5 * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 6 * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
2038            l2 = (l2 ^ (l2 >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
2039            l2 = (l2 ^ (l2 >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
2040            l2 ^= l2 >>> 31;
2041
2042            return new Mist(l1, l2);
2043        }
2044
2045        public static final Mist alpha = new Mist("alpha"), beta = new Mist("beta"), gamma = new Mist("gamma"),
2046                delta = new Mist("delta"), epsilon = new Mist("epsilon"), zeta = new Mist("zeta"),
2047                eta = new Mist("eta"), theta = new Mist("theta"), iota = new Mist("iota"),
2048                kappa = new Mist("kappa"), lambda = new Mist("lambda"), mu = new Mist("mu"),
2049                nu = new Mist("nu"), xi = new Mist("xi"), omicron = new Mist("omicron"), pi = new Mist("pi"),
2050                rho = new Mist("rho"), sigma = new Mist("sigma"), tau = new Mist("tau"),
2051                upsilon = new Mist("upsilon"), phi = new Mist("phi"), chi = new Mist("chi"), psi = new Mist("psi"),
2052                omega = new Mist("omega"),
2053                alpha_ = new Mist("ALPHA"), beta_ = new Mist("BETA"), gamma_ = new Mist("GAMMA"),
2054                delta_ = new Mist("DELTA"), epsilon_ = new Mist("EPSILON"), zeta_ = new Mist("ZETA"),
2055                eta_ = new Mist("ETA"), theta_ = new Mist("THETA"), iota_ = new Mist("IOTA"),
2056                kappa_ = new Mist("KAPPA"), lambda_ = new Mist("LAMBDA"), mu_ = new Mist("MU"),
2057                nu_ = new Mist("NU"), xi_ = new Mist("XI"), omicron_ = new Mist("OMICRON"), pi_ = new Mist("PI"),
2058                rho_ = new Mist("RHO"), sigma_ = new Mist("SIGMA"), tau_ = new Mist("TAU"),
2059                upsilon_ = new Mist("UPSILON"), phi_ = new Mist("PHI"), chi_ = new Mist("CHI"), psi_ = new Mist("PSI"),
2060                omega_ = new Mist("OMEGA");
2061        /**
2062         * Has a length of 48, which may be relevant if automatically choosing a predefined hash functor.
2063         */
2064        public static final Mist[] predefined = new Mist[]{alpha, beta, gamma, delta, epsilon, zeta, eta, theta, iota,
2065                kappa, lambda, mu, nu, xi, omicron, pi, rho, sigma, tau, upsilon, phi, chi, psi, omega,
2066                alpha_, beta_, gamma_, delta_, epsilon_, zeta_, eta_, theta_, iota_,
2067                kappa_, lambda_, mu_, nu_, xi_, omicron_, pi_, rho_, sigma_, tau_, upsilon_, phi_, chi_, psi_, omega_};

2069        public long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
2070            if (data == null)
2071                return 0;
2072            final int len = data.length;
2073            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + $l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2074            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2075                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * (data[i] ? 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L : 0x789ABCDEFEDCBA98L)) ^ $l2 * a + $l1;
2076            }
2077            return result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
2078        }

2159        /**
2160         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
2161         *
2162         * @param data  the char array to hash
2163         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
2164         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
2165         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
2166         */
2167        public long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
2168            if (data == null || start >= end)
2169                return 0;
2170            final int len = data.length;
2171            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + $l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2172            for (int i = start; i < end && i < len; i++) {
2173                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]) ^ $l2 * a + $l1;
2174            }
2175            return result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
2176        }
2177
2178        /**
2179         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
2180         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
2181         *
2182         * @param data  the char array to hash
2183         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
2184         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
2185         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
2186         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
2187         */
2188        public long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
2189            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
2190                return 0;
2191            final int len = data.length;
2192            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + $l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2193            for (int i = start; i < end && i < len; i += step) {
2194                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]) ^ $l2 * a + $l1;
2195            }
2196            return result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
2197        }

2199        public long hash64(final CharSequence data) {
2200            if (data == null)

2204            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2205                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data.charAt(i)) ^ $l2 * a + $l1;
2206            }
2207            return result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
2208        }

2373        /**
2374         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
2375         *
2376         * @param data  the char array to hash
2377         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
2378         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
2379         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
2380         */
2381        public int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
2382            if (data == null || start >= end)
2383                return 0;
2384            final int len = data.length;
2385            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + $l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2386            for (int i = start; i < end && i < len; i++) {
2387                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]) ^ $l2 * a + $l1;
2388            }
2389            return (int)(result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
2390        }
2391        /**
2392         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
2393         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
2394         *
2395         * @param data  the char array to hash
2396         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
2397         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
2398         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
2399         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
2400         */
2401        public int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
2402            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
2403                return 0;
2404            final int len = data.length;
2405            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + $l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2406            for (int i = start; i < end && i < len; i += step) {
2407                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]) ^ $l2 * a + $l1;
2408            }
2409            return (int)(result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
2410        }

2419            }
2420            return (int)(result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
2421        }

2477        public int hash(final Object[] data) {
2478            if (data == null)
2479                return 0;
2480            final int len = data.length;
2481            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + $l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2482            Object o;
2483            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2484                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * ((o = data[i]) == null ? -1 : o.hashCode())) ^ $l2 * a + $l1;
2485            }
2486            return (int)(result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
2487        }
2488
2489        public int hash(final Object data) {
2490            if (data == null)
2491                return 0;
2492            final long a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L ^ 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data.hashCode(),
2493                    result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + $l2 + (a ^ $l2 * a + $l1);
2494            return (int)(result * (a * $l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
2495        }
2496    }
2497
2498    /**
2499     * A mid-quality hashing function that has been tested with SMHasher and has passed all of it when running on
2500     * {@code byte[]} data, not larger items like {@code char[]} or {@code long[]}. The code to hash bytes is identical
2501     * in {@link Hive}, but Hive has better behavior on chars, ints, longs, and so on. You should prefer Hive, which is
2502     * now the default algorithm for {@link CrossHash#hash(CharSequence)} (as well as all overloads of hash() and
2503     * hash64() ), in place of Jolt unless you can tolerate mediocre quality when hashing ints, longs, objects, etc.
2504     * (better than Wisp, though) but do want closer speed to Wisp than Hive offers on those types.
2505     * <br>
2506     * Its design is similar to Lightning or Wisp, but it doesn't use bitwise rotations and runs what would otherwise be
2507     * the output through MurmurHash3's finalization step (its {@code fmix64()} function) at the very end. Parts of the
2508     * code here are inspired by the design of {@link LinnormRNG}, particularly its determine() method since both use an
2509     * XLCG as a processing step.
2510     */
2511    @Beta
2512    public static final class Jolt {
2513        public static long hash64(final CharSequence data) {
2514            if (data == null)
2515                return 0L;
2516            long result = 0x1A976FDF6BF60B8EL, z = 0x60642E2A34326F15L;
2517            final int len = data.length();
2518            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2519                result ^= (z += (data.charAt(i) ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L);
2520            }
2521            result += (z ^ z >>> 26) * 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2522            result ^= result >>> 25 ^ z ^ z >>> 29;
2523            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL;
2524            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L;
2525            return (result ^ result >>> 33);
2526        }
2527
2528        public static long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
2529            if (data == null)
2530                return 0L;
2531            long result = 0x1A976FDF6BF60B8EL, z = 0x60642E2A34326F15L;
2532            final int len = data.length;
2533            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2534                result ^= (z += ((data[i] ? 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL : 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L) ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L);
2535            }
2536            result += (z ^ z >>> 26) * 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2537            result ^= result >>> 25 ^ z ^ z >>> 29;
2538            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL;
2539            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L;
2540            return (result ^ result >>> 33);
2541        }

2649         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).

2653         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
2654         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
2655         */
2656        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
2657            if (data == null || start >= end)
2658                return 0L;
2659            long result = 0x1A976FDF6BF60B8EL, z = 0x60642E2A34326F15L;
2660            final int len = end < data.length ? end : data.length;
2661            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
2662                result ^= (z += (data[i] ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L);
2663            }
2664            result += (z ^ z >>> 26) * 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2665            result ^= result >>> 25 ^ z ^ z >>> 29;
2666            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL;
2667            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L;
2668            return (result ^ result >>> 33);
2669        }

2804        public static long hash64(final CharSequence[]... data) {
2805            if (data == null)

2808            final int len = data.length;
2809            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2810                result ^= (z += (hash64(data[i]) ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L);

2815            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L;
2816            return (result ^ result >>> 33);

3009        /**
3010         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
3011         *
3012         * @param data  the char array to hash
3013         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
3014         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
3015         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
3016         */
3017        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
3018            if (data == null || start >= end)
3019                return 0;
3020            long result = 0x1A976FDF6BF60B8EL, z = 0x60642E2A34326F15L;
3021            final int len = end < data.length ? end : data.length;
3022            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
3023                result ^= (z += (data[i] ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L);
3024            }
3025            result += (z ^ z >>> 26) * 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
3026            result ^= result >>> 25 ^ z ^ z >>> 29;
3027            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL;
3028            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L;
3029            return (int) (result ^ result >>> 33);
3030        }

3055        /**
3056         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
3057         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
3058         *
3059         * @param data  the char array to hash
3060         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
3061         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
3062         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
3063         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
3064         */
3065        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
3066            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
3067                return 0;
3068            long result = 0x1A976FDF6BF60B8EL, z = 0x60642E2A34326F15L;
3069            final int len = end < data.length ? end : data.length;
3070            for (int i = start; i < len; i += step) {
3071                result ^= (z += (data[i] ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L);
3072            }
3073            result += (z ^ z >>> 26) * 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
3074            result ^= result >>> 25 ^ z ^ z >>> 29;
3075            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL;
3076            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L;
3077            return (int) (result ^ result >>> 33);
3078        }
